3. Evaluate the fitness of each solution in the population using the objective function f(x) = -x^2 + 2x + 5.

4. For each iteration:
   a. Perform the employed bee phase: Update the solutions by generating new solutions in the neighborhood of the current solutions, and evaluate their fitness. If the new solution has better fitness, replace the old solution with the new one.
   b. Perform the onlooker bee phase: Select the solutions with higher fitness probabilistically, and update them similarly to the employed bee phase.
   c. Perform the scout bee phase: If a solution has not been improved for a certain number of iterations (called the "limit" parameter), replace it with a new randomly generated solution.
   d. Update the best solution found so far, if a better solution is found in the current iteration.
   e. Repeat steps 4a to 4d until the maximum number of iterations (max_iter) is reached.

5. The best solution found after max_iter iterations will be the optimal value of x, and the minimum value of the function can be obtained by evaluating f(x) at this optimal value.
